body: Thanks for review @chamikaramj. Please take a look now. Thanks.

R: @kennknowles 

This is mostly a refactoring of `ExecutorServiceParallelExecutor` into multiple interfaces and independent components. Logic shouldn't have changed (and given that the TestStream tests still pass, I'm convinced that quiescence properties have been maintained)
Please make sure that any pom.xml changes show up in the build.gradle file as well.
LGTM & looks like Gradle is happy with this.
Gradle already appears to include a dependency on mockito which permits this to build.
Test timing out, will attempt a 3rd run. Perhaps related to https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/BEAM-3040

FYI, I've been going through this PR as well.

For the ReferenceRunner, I'm not hugely concerned with the resource usage per job submission. However; it would be preferable to have only a single instance in order to ensure that clients are setting appropriate metadata to stage files in the correct location.
Jenkins configs were broken when this ran.
Jenkins failure is findbugs not liking you ignoring return values.

R: @tvalentyn 

This should fix failures such as https://builds.apache.org/job/beam_PreCommit_Python_MavenInstall/org.apache.beam$beam-sdks-python/899/console

Jenkins: retest this please

Failed due to issue fixed by https://github.com/apache/beam/pull/4156
The  ./gradlew --continue --rerun-tasks :javaPreCommit supersedes the older gradle run.

A typical maven issue was that multiple runs of the same test for integration testing would overwrite itself but are correctly appearing in the Jenkins UI for Gradle builds, see https://builds.apache.org/job/beam_PreCommit_Java_GradleBuild/45/testReport/org.apache.beam.examples/WordCountIT/
LGTM. Thank you @robertwb. This is awesome.

Postcommit suite does not run against this PR - it runs against master. We can see in the job logs that we are still using old container. Verified locally that offending postcommit test passes.
cc: @angoenka 
R: @aaltay  - please merge this when you have a chance. Thank you.
R: @tgroh I think I did the proper fix now? Does this look good
PTAL; both gradle and maven build sucessfully
LGTM. Thank you. Please monitor tests after the merge.

Ok, this should be ok now, I just rebased and made the exception testing methods of ParDoLifecycleTest part of the ValidatesRunner test suite, notice that if you executed this before it broke for the SparkRunner, so it seems we should be ok now. Waiting for feedback/merge in case you find it is ok.
Thanks for the update. I gonna take a look.
Closing this, we may not be ready for this change.
Postcommit suite still fails, and looking at the logs, the change has not been picked up  - we are still using old container name that is no longer in the code.

@iemejia @kennknowles , I have rebased and created a separate PR for the largest commit here: https://github.com/apache/beam/pull/4165 . Would this be easier to review? If yes, then I'll split this PR into few more smaller ones and close this one. 

@xumingming I addressed the feedback in https://github.com/apache/beam/pull/4165

Postcommit issue is tracked in https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/BEAM-3120.

For the record, to verify the test manually, run in a virtual environment: 

python setup.py sdist
pip install -e .[gcp,test]

PROJECT="myorg:myproject";\
GCS_LOCATION="gs://mybucket";\
SDK_LOCATION=$(find dist/apache-beam-*.tar.gz);\
nosetests ./apache_beam/examples/wordcount_it_test.py:WordCountIT.test_wordcount_fnapi_it --test-pipeline-options=" \
    --runner=TestDataflowRunner \
    --project=$PROJECT \
    --staging_location=$GCS_LOCATION/staging-it \
    --temp_location=$GCS_LOCATION/temp-it \
    --output=$GCS_LOCATION/py-it-cloud/output \
    --sdk_location=$SDK_LOCATION \
    --num_workers=1 \
    --sleep_secs=20"
@chamikaramj Thanks for reviewing! Please take another look when you get the chance.
LGTM, unfortunate about the Java 7 downgrade.
Luckily runner authors building with Java should still be able to use lambdas, method references, and so on; it's only the library implementations that have to change.
Hi @chamikaramj , can you please take a look? This allow to switch between filesystems by adding system property -Dfilesystem and provide filesystem specific pipeline options.
As part of the solution for the issue on the Spark runner (see BEAM-3187) I consider that enabling these tests for all runners makes sense.

I like this idea!

One minor comment: Can we put the `BeamRecordSqlTypeBuilder` inside `BeamRecordSqlType`? it will keep the surface api of `org.apache.beam.sdk.extensions.sql` cleaner.
@chamikaramj thanks for the review! Here's another batch of changes, as commented above.

Using multiple anonymous DoFn's with the same enclosing class within the same composite transform is already possible if you specify the transform name in .apply() - e.g.: .apply("Something", ParDo.of(new DoFn..)).apply("Something else", ParDo.of(new DoFn..)). This is a good thing rather than a bug, because using generated names like `Enclosing$1` is unstable w.r.t. pipeline update: any reordering of the anonymous classes, or adding a new one, or making an existing one be non-anonymous, will change the numbering and make the pipeline update-incompatible.

I understand where it comes from but it is very boring when writing tests where it is not uncommon to write anonymous classes and the inline naming is not always doable when you write utility methods or reusable piece of pipelines.

You would also note that anonymous algorithm with the "number" is somehow aligned on the fact to keep only the suffix in the nested class case which leads to as meaningless names (Important$Stuff leads to Stuff which is in general not very meaningful for the "task" context since it is hold by the enclosing class to avoid long and repeating names).

The original issue is when it fails it is quite abstract and not very obvious. An alternative can be to enrich the error message with:

1. where the anonymous *classes* (all conflicting ones) are
2. how to fix it - passing a name to the apply

I would be fine with this "not solution" fix as well, does it sound better for you?

Yeah, I would prefer an improved error message. I suppose you mean the message that says `Transform Foo does not have a stable unique name. This will prevent reloading of pipelines.` - that message definitely should point to specifying the name in .apply() as a fix.

Something like
 
    Transform Foo$1 conflicts with Foo$2 in pipeline defined in MyTest line 56. You can fix it adding a name in apply invocations line 54 and 52.

The long name is important cause otherwise you have no clue of the provenance.
Following the vote on the mailing lists, I updated the PR with Spark 2.x update only (no support of Spark 1 anymore).

Seems like a good idea, though please bring it up on the mailing list - I think it's been discussed before and it'd be good if people who participated in that discussion chimed in. As a workaround, I typically use `-pl sdks/java/core -am -amd`.

Please ping the thread when the PR is ready for review. I think you said on the mailing list that some tests are still pending? And, since this is a major change, please also run the ValidatesRunner tests and I think it'd be prudent to perform the typical manual release validation steps (quickstart, game examples) against a real Spark cluster.
@kennknowles @jasonkuster @lukecwik - Do we have a process to test groovy changes before the commit?
You can `run seed job` and it will actually be installed right away. It can then be rolled back if broken. Other than that, you need to have a test Jenkins cluster, which is a bit of work.
